subject: long instead of string Re: JUnit issues
msgSnippet: Robert, i appreciate the reply. I got the bug fixed. (was coz of a System.exit in teardown method that caused the program execution to get stuck). Was wanting
messageBody:
Robert,

i appreciate the reply.
I got the bug fixed. (was coz of a System.exit in teardown method
that caused the program execution to get stuck).

Was wanting to know if assertNotNull can be used to ascertain about
long instead of string

havent found this in Junit documentation.

Thanks.


--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Robert Wenner <robert@p...> wrote:
> On Tuesday 20 January 2004 16:13, asamyuktav wrote:
> > It runs first test but not the second.
>
> Do you build your test suite manually, i.e. in a suite() method?
Did you
> forget to add the second test?
>
> > Assert True is not working
>
> I use assertTrue, that works.
>
> > (not printing test results/statistics..)
>
> assertTrue does not print anything, just decide whether the
assertion
> holds or not (and then throw).
>
> > public void testFuture() throws Exception {
> >
> > try {
> >
> > server.start();
> > myClass.waitForValue(3001);
> > String receivedString = (String) myClass.getValue();
> >
> > Assert.assertTrue(receivedString.equals
> > (stringToSend));
>
> Why not use assertEquals here?
>
> > } catch (Exception e) {
> >
> > System.out.println("Excepion is:"+e);
> > }
>
> Why do you need that debugging output?
>
> > Assert.assertTrue(true);
>
> You can write this shorter: use just a semicolon.
>
> Maybe you could provide the whole test class, I left my crystal
ball in
> the other trousers.
>
> Anyway, some guesses:
>
> Does your test class extend TestCase? (If yes, why do you write
> Assert.assert... ?)
> Did you read the documentation that comes with JUnit?
>
>
> Robert
